title: Boris Johnson had ‘no role’ in allocation of public money to American model
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson after speaking at the U.N. General Assembly | Spencer Platt/Getty Images Boris Johnson had ‘no role’ in allocation of public money to American model There was nothing ‘untoward’ about the award of a grant to Jennifer Arcuri, says minister.

LONDON — Boris Johnson “had absolutely no role” in the government’s decision to grant a £126,000 grant to Jennifer Arcuri, an American model turned technology entrepreneur, a government minister said.

Digital minister Matt Warman told the House of Commons that the grant had been awarded “by officials through the proper process.”

The Sunday Times reported on September 22 that Arcuri had been awarded £126,000 in public money and was given privileged access to three foreign trade missions led by Johnson.

Asking an urgent question in the Commons, Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran said: “The fact that we are back in the Commons today is because the prime minister has been shown to ride rough-shod over the laws of this land. It would indeed be disappointing if we were to find that the prime minister has form in bending the rules for personal or political gain.”

In response, Warman said: “The prime minister and his staff have had absolutely no role in the award of this grant.”

“We have no reason to think there is anything untoward in this particular matter,” he added.

Shadow culture secretary and Labour deputy leader Tom Watson said it was “very difficult” to see how the company, registered in the U.S., fulfilled the criteria for the grants. He said the case posed questions about whether Johnson was suitable to occupy high office and disburse public funds.

“The truth is that our Prime Minister does reckless things. He is a man whose character renders him unsuitable and unfit for the office he holds.”
description: There was nothing ‘untoward’ about the award of a grant to Jennifer Arcuri, says minister.
